intro: Quercus baronii, commonly known as the Barrow oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its broad, ovate leaves that turn yellow in the fall. The tree produces small, bell-shaped flowers in the spring, followed by acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Quercus baronii typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in bottomlands and swamps. Its ecological importance lies in its role as a habitat provider and its contribution to forest biodiversity.
